title: 111_s3029
content: The "StartUp Visa Act of 2010" may be cited as the StartUp Visa Act. It includes provisions for startup visas. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs who have received investments of at least $100,000 and will create a minimum of 5 new full-time jobs in the US within a 2-year period. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs who must create at least 5 new full-time jobs in the US, raise $1,000,000 in capital investment, or generate $1,000,000 in revenue. A qualified super angel investor is defined as an accredited US citizen. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs who must create at least 5 new full-time jobs in the US, raise $1,000,000 in capital investment, or generate $1,000,000 in revenue. A qualified super angel investor is defined as an accredited US citizen. A qualified venture capitalist is an entity classified as a 'venture capital operating company' under specific regulations, based in the US, with majority US citizen partners, and capital commitments of at least $10,000,000. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs who must create at least 5 new full-time jobs in the US, raise $1,000,000 in capital investment, or generate $1,000,000 in revenue. The Act defines a qualified super angel investor as an accredited US citizen and a qualified venture capitalist as an entity with capital commitments of at least $10,000,000. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs who must meet specific job creation, capital investment, or revenue generation requirements. The Act also includes provisions for sponsored entrepreneurs, where their permanent resident status can be terminated if certain conditions are not met within 3 years. The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs, including provisions for sponsored entrepreneurs. Changes in subsections include inserting "sponsored entrepreneur" after "alien entrepreneur" and replacing "alien entrepreneur must" with "entrepreneur shall." The StartUp Visa Act of 2010 introduces StartUp visas for qualified immigrant entrepreneurs, including provisions for sponsored entrepreneurs. The term "sponsored entrepreneur" is defined as an alien who obtains lawful permanent residence under section 203(b)(6).
